ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Philosophical problems, dilemmas, and questions in recent history
How to approach incredibly dense philosophical texts
How to better structure and organize papers
Improved ability to write philosophy paper, critique arguments and debate philosophical questions.
I gained deeper insight into my beliefs and thoroughly improved my ability to deconstruct a philosophers argument
I learned how to dissect an argument down to its barest bones and communicate my ideas clearly and effectively.
Analyzing philosophical arguments, thinking more critically about a difficult text and discussing it with peers, writing more clearly and concisely
Rigorous reconstruction and interpretation of philosophical arguments. Expression thereof in short written papers.

an ability to clearly understand and interpret VERY complex and transformative philosophical ideas and an ability to think critically about these incredibly murky ideas so as to find holes in arguments (objections)
I gained a working knowledge of many of the main strands of post-renaissance European philosophy, including many completely novel ideas like ambiguity, freedom, Spinozic gods, etc.
I developed knowledge regarding the history of philosophy and skills necessary to read and understand philosophic texts.

This semester's syllabus was full of really provocative, bold ideas about ethics, epistemology and metaphysics. This course teaches you not only how to reckon with these arguments and their implications but also how the different models complement and conflict.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Selecting different material. To be sure, many of the thinkers we read were formidable and offered impressive theories. But philosophers like Conway & Ryle were just... uninteresting. Even the lectures struggled to make them exciting. Cutting away excesses like these may make the class more engaging.
Philosophy is an amazing class!  I was able to fledge out my argumentative wings much more this semester and make friendships with everyone from Descartes to Kant.
I found it helpful when the professor guided the discussion and went over the text more slowly. I think one way that the class could improve is if it has reading questions to focus the reading.

DRST 004 has a refined and well-considered approach to understanding complex and difficult readings. We often had more reading than we could feasibly discuss in seminar, particularly with Kant's Critique of Pure Reason. The course would be improved by removing Ryle and giving an extra class on Murdoch.

The DS curriculum this semester was great with a lot of diverse and interesting thinkersalthough I thought Hegel and Nietzsche would have been cool to read in philosophy instead of H&P...The course of was on Zoom so that was an obvious weakness but Professor Kronman and his feedback on papers were amazing. Even on Zoom, he kept class interesting.

Like all courses taught over zoom, it was sometimes difficult to engage with the class. I'm hesitant to list specific criticisms because I feel like most of them would be addressed by the class being taught in person. The seminars were illuminating and enjoyable. If anything, I would have liked to have more of a discussion of KantProf. Kronman mostly lectured about his work, which was useful, but more difficult to retain than regular discussion.

I think this was a strong and enjoyable course. It claims it will provide a survey of western philosophical thought and does precisely that. My understanding of philosophy and how to write and think about philosophy has been greatly improved due to this course.
The syllabus is excellent and class conversation generally was stimulating. The discussion was much too guided however.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual lectures definitely succeeded. I dont know what really failed given that Im a first year
This course worked just fine during the pandemic.  I was engaged (and very often lost) in thought for the entire semester!
I think the zoom classes and zoom office hours were held very efficiently!
Virtual seminar was smooth and satisfying. Recorded lectures lacked accountability, and I lacked motivation to watch them.
Zoom had a lot of problems and did not allow for much student engagement and there weren't many other practices in the course besides the seminar that enhanced learning during the pandemic
There were some wifi problems, but those were resolved.
The course was essentially just a normal seminar through zoom so I have no comment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!!!
Yes. Great professor, great books, great discussion

Absolutely. If the student cares about learning more about what they believe, and why they believe it, take DS philosophy! Pop phil classes are nothing like these. Dive into epistemology, explore ontology. Ethics are cool, but we all already have ideas of whats right and wrong. Solutions to the mind-body problem, though... now THAT is contentious.
Definitely!  You get to learn from some of the greatest thinkers and explore what they each have to offer.
I would recommend this because it is an extremely insightful class that applies to other academic realms beyond philosophy. It deepens your thinking and challenges your assumptions.

Yes. I was unenthusiastic about DS after the first semester. The second semester was excellent. My classmates were more comfortable and confident in seminar, and the readings were more interesting and relevant. Having the first semester as foundation helped reveal the interconnectedness of the DS philosophical canon, and DRST 004 gives satisfying completion.

Yes. Philosophy with Professor Kronman was a difficult, but awesome experience. DS Philosophy is going to be hard (Kant!!) but Professor Kronman is an expert and his ability to explain things clearly and interestingly is unparalleled.

Yes definitely! Honestly this course and many of the concepts introduced by 19th and 20th century authors revived my interest in philosophy. Even the ancient philosophy I had disagreed with previously became more interesting because it became presented as a school of thought in dialogue with modern philosophy, rather than an overbearing, unquestioned canon.

Yes, I would recommend directed studies without hesitation. The spring philosophy section provides deep and compelling insight into many of the most famous and influential answers to important questions regarding thought, space, time, morality, and more.

The workload is not for everyone and you need to carefully consider whether you want to spend over an hour every day reading dense philosophical texts sometimes without much thanks. But if you're willing to commit to it, you get a pretty useful vocabulary of ideas along with a sharpened sense for logical reasoning.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual lectures
Seminars paired with a weekly lecture.
recorded lecture and virtual seminar
recorded lecture
zoom seminar + lectures
Also weekly lectures
none
